metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: SQL AUTO INCREMENT Field
AUTO INCREMENT Field
Auto-increment allows a unique number to be generated automatically when a new record is inserted into a table.
content.html: Auto-increment allows a unique number to be generated automatically when a new record is inserted into a table.

content.text: Often this is the primary key field that we would like to be created automatically every time a new record is inserted.
content.html: Often this is the primary key field that we would like to be created automatically every time a new record is inserted.

content.text: Syntax for MySQL
The following SQL statement defines the "Personid" column to be an auto-increment primary key field in the "Persons" table:
content.html: The following SQL statement defines the "Personid" column to be an auto-increment primary key field in the "Persons" table:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
CREATE TABLE Persons
(
    
  Personid int NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
   
LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,
   
FirstName varchar(255),
    Age int,
   
PRIMARY KEY (Personid)
);

content.code:
CREATE TABLE Persons
(

Personid int NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,

LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,

FirstName varchar(255),
Age int,

PRIMARY KEY (Personid)
);

syntax_highlighting.text:
CREATE TABLE Persons
(
    
  Personid int NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
   
LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,
   
FirstName varchar(255),
    Age int,
   
PRIMARY KEY (Personid)
);

content.code_html:
CREATE TABLE Persons (
    Personid int NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
    LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,
    FirstName varchar(255),
    Age int,
    PRIMARY KEY (Personid)
);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
CREATE TABLE Persons
(
    
  Personid int NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
   
LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,
   
FirstName varchar(255),
    Age int,
   
PRIMARY KEY (Personid)
);

content.text: MySQL uses the AUTO_INCREMENT keyword to perform an auto-increment feature.
content.html: MySQL uses the AUTO_INCREMENT keyword to perform an auto-increment feature.

content.text: By default, the starting value for AUTO_INCREMENT is 1, and it will increment by 1 for each new record.
content.html: By default, the starting value for AUTO_INCREMENT is 1, and it will increment by 1 for each new record.

content.text: To let the AUTO_INCREMENT sequence start with another value, use the following SQL statement:
content.html: To let the AUTO_INCREMENT sequence start with another value, use the following SQL statement:

content.code_html: ALTER TABLE Persons AUTO_INCREMENT=100;

content.text: To insert a new record into the "Persons" table, we will NOT have to specify a value for the "Personid" column (a unique value will be added automatically):
content.html: To insert a new record into the "Persons" table, we will NOT have to specify a value for the "Personid" column (a unique value will be added automatically):

content.code_html:
INSERT INTO Persons (FirstName,LastName)
VALUES ('Lars','Monsen');

content.text: The SQL statement above would insert a new record into the "Persons" table. The "Personid" column would be assigned a unique value. The "FirstName" column would be set to "Lars" and the "LastName" column would be set to "Monsen".
content.html: The SQL statement above would insert a new record into the "Persons" table. The "Personid" column would be assigned a unique value. The "FirstName" column would be set to "Lars" and the "LastName" column would be set to "Monsen".

content.text: Syntax for SQL Server
The following SQL statement defines the "Personid" column to be an auto-increment primary key field in the "Persons" table:
content.html: The following SQL statement defines the "Personid" column to be an auto-increment primary key field in the "Persons" table:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
CREATE TABLE Persons
(
    
  Personid int IDENTITY(1,1) PRIMARY KEY,
   
LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,
   
FirstName varchar(255),
   
Age int
);

content.code:
CREATE TABLE Persons
(

Personid int IDENTITY(1,1) PRIMARY KEY,

LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,

FirstName varchar(255),

Age int
);

syntax_highlighting.text:
CREATE TABLE Persons
(
    
  Personid int IDENTITY(1,1) PRIMARY KEY,
   
LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,
   
FirstName varchar(255),
   
Age int
);

content.code_html:
CREATE TABLE Persons (
    Personid int IDENTITY(1,1) PRIMARY KEY,
    LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,
    FirstName varchar(255),
    Age int
);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
CREATE TABLE Persons
(
    
  Personid int IDENTITY(1,1) PRIMARY KEY,
   
LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,
   
FirstName varchar(255),
   
Age int
);

content.text: The MS SQL Server uses the IDENTITY keyword to perform an auto-increment feature.
content.html: The MS SQL Server uses the IDENTITY keyword to perform an auto-increment feature.

content.text: In the example above, the starting value for IDENTITY is 1, and it will increment by 1 for each new record.
content.html: In the example above, the starting value for IDENTITY is 1, and it will increment by 1 for each new record.

content.text: Tip: To specify that the "Personid" column should start at value 10 and increment by 5, change it to IDENTITY(10,5) .
content.html: Tip: To specify that the "Personid" column should start at value 10 and increment by 5, change it to IDENTITY(10,5).

content.text: To insert a new record into the "Persons" table, we will NOT have to specify a value for the "Personid" column (a unique value will be added automatically):
content.html: To insert a new record into the "Persons" table, we will NOT have to specify a value for the "Personid" column (a unique value will be added automatically):

content.code_html:
INSERT INTO Persons (FirstName,LastName)
VALUES ('Lars','Monsen');

content.text: The SQL statement above would insert a new record into the "Persons" table. The "Personid" column would be assigned a unique value. The "FirstName" column would be set to "Lars" and the "LastName" column would be set to "Monsen".
content.html: The SQL statement above would insert a new record into the "Persons" table. The "Personid" column would be assigned a unique value. The "FirstName" column would be set to "Lars" and the "LastName" column would be set to "Monsen".

content.text: Syntax for Access
The following SQL statement defines the "Personid" column to be an auto-increment primary key field in the "Persons" table:
content.html: The following SQL statement defines the "Personid" column to be an auto-increment primary key field in the "Persons" table:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
CREATE TABLE Persons
(
    
  Personid AUTOINCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
   
LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,
   
FirstName varchar(255),
   
Age int
);

content.code:
CREATE TABLE Persons
(

Personid AUTOINCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,

LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,

FirstName varchar(255),

Age int
);

syntax_highlighting.text:

(
    
  Personid AUTOINCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
   
LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,
   
FirstName varchar(255),
   
Age int
);

content.code_html:
CREATE TABLE Persons (
    Personid AUTOINCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
    LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,
    FirstName varchar(255),
    Age int
);

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
CREATE TABLE Persons
(
    
  Personid AUTOINCREMENT PRIMARY KEY,
   
LastName varchar(255) NOT NULL,
   
FirstName varchar(255),
   
Age int
);

content.text: The MS Access uses the AUTOINCREMENT keyword to perform an auto-increment feature.
content.html: The MS Access uses the AUTOINCREMENT keyword to perform an auto-increment feature.

content.text: By default, the starting value for AUTOINCREMENT is 1, and it will increment by 1 for each new record.
content.html: By default, the starting value for AUTOINCREMENT is 1, and it will increment by 1 for each new record.

content.text: Tip: To specify that the "Personid" column should start at value 10 and increment by 5, change the autoincrement to AUTOINCREMENT(10,5) .
content.html: Tip: To specify that the "Personid" column should start at value 10 and increment by 5, change the autoincrement to AUTOINCREMENT(10,5).

content.text: To insert a new record into the "Persons" table, we will NOT have to specify a value for the "Personid" column (a unique value will be added automatically):
content.html: To insert a new record into the "Persons" table, we will NOT have to specify a value for the "Personid" column (a unique value will be added automatically):

content.code_html:
INSERT INTO Persons (FirstName,LastName)
VALUES ('Lars','Monsen');

content.text: The SQL statement above would insert a new record into the "Persons" table. The "Personid" column would be assigned a unique value. The "FirstName" column would be set to "Lars" and the "LastName" column would be set to "Monsen".
content.html: The SQL statement above would insert a new record into the "Persons" table. The "Personid" column would be assigned a unique value. The "FirstName" column would be set to "Lars" and the "LastName" column would be set to "Monsen".

content.text: Syntax for Oracle
In Oracle the code is a little bit more tricky.
content.html: In Oracle the code is a little bit more tricky.

content.text: You will have to create an auto-increment field with the sequence object (this object generates a number sequence).
content.html: You will have to create an auto-increment field with the sequence object (this object generates a number sequence).

content.text: Use the following CREATE SEQUENCE syntax:
content.html: Use the following CREATE SEQUENCE syntax:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
CREATE SEQUENCE seq_person
MINVALUE 1
START WITH 1
INCREMENT BY 1
CACHE 10;

content.code:
CREATE SEQUENCE seq_person
MINVALUE 1
START WITH 1
INCREMENT BY 1
CACHE 10;

syntax_highlighting.text:
CREATE SEQUENCE seq_person
MINVALUE 1
START WITH 1
INCREMENT BY 1
CACHE 10;

content.code_html:
CREATE SEQUENCE seq_person
MINVALUE 1
START WITH 1
INCREMENT BY 1
CACHE 10;

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
CREATE SEQUENCE seq_person
MINVALUE 1
START WITH 1
INCREMENT BY 1
CACHE 10;

content.text: The code above creates a sequence object called seq_person, that starts with 1 and will increment by 1. It will also cache up to 10 values for performance. The cache option specifies how many sequence values will be stored in memory for faster access.
content.html: The code above creates a sequence object called seq_person, that starts with 1 and will increment by 1. It will also cache up to 10 values for performance. The cache option specifies how many sequence values will be stored in memory for faster access.

content.text: To insert a new record into the "Persons" table, we will have to use the nextval function (this function retrieves the next value from seq_person sequence):
content.html: To insert a new record into the "Persons" table, we will have to use the nextval function (this function retrieves the next value from seq_person sequence):

content.code_html:
INSERT INTO Persons (Personid,FirstName,LastName)
VALUES (seq_person.nextval,'Lars','Monsen');

content.text: The SQL statement above would insert a new record into the "Persons" table. The "Personid" column would be assigned the next number from the seq_person sequence. The "FirstName" column would be set to "Lars" and the "LastName" column would be set to "Monsen".
content.html: The SQL statement above would insert a new record into the "Persons" table. The "Personid" column would be assigned the next number from the seq_person sequence. The "FirstName" column would be set to "Lars" and the "LastName" column would be set to "Monsen".
